Package lab1

Class RecursiveMethods

java.lang.Object
lab1.RecursiveMethods
public class RecursiveMethods
extends java.lang.Object
Lab1 Requirement: You are required to implement all methods recursively. You receive a zero if there is any occurrence of a loop (e.g., for, while).

Do not use a loop. Use only recursion. Solutions using loop will not receive credit.

Hint: For some of the public recursive methods in RecursiveMethods class you may consider adding private recursive helper methods.

  • Method Details

    • fibArray

      public int[] fibArray​(int n)
      Return an array storing the first n numbers in a Fibonacci sequence. The Fibonacci starts with the first two numbers being 1 and 1, then starting from the 3rd number, it is the sum of the previous two numbers. You can assume that n is positive. e.g., fibArray(5) returns an array {1, 1, 2, 3, 5}.
      Parameters:
      n - the first n Fibonacci numbers
      Returns:
      an array representing the first n Fibonacci numbers You are forbidden to use the fibList method below to solve this problem. Requirement: You are required to implement all methods recursively. You receive a zero if there is any occurrence of a loop (e.g., for, while).

    • isRelativelyPrime

      public boolean isRelativelyPrime​(int p, int q)

      This method determine if p and q are relatively prime.

      Two integers p and q are said to be relatively Prime if the Greatest Common Divisor of them is 1.

      Hints:

      A positive integer n > 1 is called prime if the only positive factors of n are 1 and n . A positive integer that is greater than one and is not prime is called composite.

      An integer n is composite if and only if there exists an integer a such that a divides n and 1 < a < n.

      Hint: 1 is neither prime nor composite. It forms its own special category as a "unit".

      This method checks the two positive integers are relatively prime or not.

        Example:
  
  
  isRelativelyPrime (8, 6) returns false
  isRelativelyPrime (15, 25) returns false
  isRelativelyPrime (7, 2) returns true 
  isRelativelyPrime (19, 3) returns true 
  isRelativelyPrime (11, 13) returns true 
  isRelativelyPrime (21, 17) returns true 
  isRelativelyPrime (17, 29) returns true
      Parameters:
      p - positive integer
      q - positive integer
      Returns:
      true if p and q are relatively prime, else false
      Precondition:
      p > 0 and q > 0

    • IntegerToBinary

      public int[] IntegerToBinary​(int n)

      Write a recursive function convert any decimal number n > 0 and n <= 65535 into a binary number, return an array represents the binary number

      a binary (base-2) number. A binary number is made up of one or more binary digits called bits. A bit has a value that is equal to either 0 or 1. 

        Example:
  
 IntegerToBinary (4)  return [0, 0, 1], where (0*1)+(0*2)+(1*4) = 4 
 IntegerToBinary (9)  return [1, 0, 0, 1], where (1*1)+(0*2)+(0*4)+(1*8) = 9
 IntegerToBinary (31)  return [1, 1, 1, 1, 1], where (1*1)+(1*2)+(1*4)+(1*8)+(1*16) =31
      Parameters:
      n - positive integer
      Returns:
      array represents the binary number
      Precondition:
      n > 0

    • complementofDecimal

      public java.lang.String complementofDecimal​(int n)

      Write a recursive function returns the complement of decimal integer n, as a String.The complement of integer n is defined as follows: (1) a 0 in n's decimal representation is replaced by 9 . (2) a digit d > 0 in n's decimal representation is replaced by 10-d. 

        Example:
  for n = 43, return "67" and for n = 10203, return "99897"
      Parameters:
      n - integer
      Returns:
      string complement of the decimal integer as defined above
      Precondition:
      n > 0

    • numberOfFirstChar

      public int numberOfFirstChar​(java.lang.String str)

      Write a recursive function numberOfFirstChar returns the number of times the first char of string str appears at the beginning of string str.

      Hint: You can String functions such as charAt, length, and substring.

        Example:
  numberOfFirstChar("")  return 0 , empty string 
  numberOfFirstChar("bbbcfreb$b") return  3
  numberOfFirstChar("beqecb$bbb") return  1
      Parameters:
      str - is not null String
      Returns:
      the number of times the first char of string str appears at the beginning of string str.
      Precondition:
      str is not null String

    • compressString

      public java.lang.String compressString​(java.lang.String str)

      Write a recursive function compressString that compression long String str that contain many adjacent equal characters (but no digits). 

        Example:
  compressString("")  return "" , empty string 
  compressString("bbbcfreb$b") return  "b3c1f1r1e1b1$1b1"
  compressString("bbbrrraaaaaazzzz") return  "b3r3a6z4"
      Parameters:
      str - : string to be compressed, str is not null
      Returns:
      the compressed version of long string as explained above
      Precondition:
      Precondition: s does not contain a digit in '0'.. '9'., str is not null String and str does not contain a digit in '0'.. '9'.

    • yorknacci

      public int yorknacci​(int n)

      Write a recursive function returns Yorknacci number y(n).

      Recall the Fibonacci numbers: Fibonacci number an is defined as the sum of the 2 previous Fibonacci numbers: a(n) = a(n-1)+a(n-2), with a(0) =0, a(1) = a(2) = 1.. Based on Fibonacci numbers, we define the Yorknacci numbers as the list of numbers where Yorknacci number y(n) is defined as the sum of the previous 3 Yorknacci numbers if n is odd and the sum of the previous 2 Yorknacci numbers if n is even. The first three Yorknacci numbers y(0), y(1), and y(2) are 1. y(0)=y(1)=y(2)=1 

        Example:
  yorknacci(0)  return 1 
  yorknacci(1)  return 1
  yorknacci(2)  return 1
  yorknacci(3)  return 3
  yorknacci(4)  return 4    
  yorknacci(5)  return 8
      Parameters:
      n - : integer value for Yorknacci, n>=0
      Returns:
      Return Yorknacci number y(n).
      Precondition:
      n>=0

    • YorknacciList

      public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> YorknacciList​(int n)

      Write a recursive function returns a list storing the first n numbers in a Yorknacci sequence.

      The Yorknacci number is defined above. ( check the API of yorknacci method)

      You can assume that n is n>1. e.g., YorknacciList(5) returns a list {y(0), y(1), y(2), y(3) , y(4)}= {1, 1, 1, 3, 4}. 

        Example:
  YorknacciList(2)  return {1, 1} 
  YorknacciList(3)  return {1, 1, 1}
  YorknacciList(5)  return {1, 1, 1, 3, 4}
      Parameters:
      n - the first n Yorknacci numbers
      Returns:
      a list representing the first n Yorknacci numbers
      Precondition:
      n>1

    • repeatCharNTimes

      public java.lang.String repeatCharNTimes​(int n, char c)

      Write a recursive function returns a String containing n occurrences of character c . 

        Example:
  repeatCharNTimes(2, 'd')  return  "dd"
  repeatCharNTimes(3, 'c')  return  "ccc"
  repeatCharNTimes(5, 'a')  return  "aaaaa"
      Parameters:
      n - : Number of occurrence
      c - : Char to be repeated
      Returns:
      return String containing n occurrences of character c.
      Precondition:
      n >= 0.

    • expandCompressedString

      public java.lang.String expandCompressedString​(java.lang.String str)

      Write a recursive function returns String s but with each pair "ci" of characters, where i is a digit, replaced by i occurrences of c. 

        Example:
  expandCompressedString("d2")  return  "dd"
  expandCompressedString("c3d2")  return  "cccdd"
  expandCompressedString("a5x4f1")  return  "aaaaaxxxxf"
  expandCompressedString("a5x0f1")  return  "aaaaaf"
      Parameters:
      str - input compressed String
      Returns:
      a String Expansion of compressed string
      Precondition:
      str contains an even number of characters, and the first of each pair is a char and the second is a digit.

    • IntegerToOctal

      public int[] IntegerToOctal​(int n)

      Write a recursive function convert any decimal number n > 0 and n <= 65535 into a octal number, return an array represents the octal number

      A octal (base-8) number. A octal number is made up of one or more octal digits {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7}. 

        Example:
  
 IntegerToOctal (4)  return [4], where (4*1) = 4 
 IntegerToOctal (9)  return [1, 1], where (1*1)+(1*8) = 9
 IntegerToOctal (31)  return [7, 3], where (7*1)+(3*8) =31
 
 IntegerToOctal (65535)  return [7, 7, 7, 7, 7, 1], 
                where (7*1)+(7*8)+ (7*64)+ (7*512)+(7*4096)+ (1*32768) =65535
      Parameters:
      n - positive integer
      Returns:
      array represents the octal number
      Precondition:
      n > 0
